Award.AwardTitle: Accelerating Systemic Change Network Inaugural Network Meeting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is the inaugural workshop meeting of a new STEM Education research network calling itself the Accelerating Systemic Change Network (ASCN). At the workshop the main agenda Item is to strategically plan the growth of the network to bring it to the point where it can support fledgling efforts in departments and institutions to transform their teaching and learning practices. At this meeting, working groups will be established and working group members will share their own work with one another, establish an agenda for their group, and articulate their vision and goals for the larger network.

The intellectual merit and the broader impacts of supporting the start-up of the ASCN is that this will expand the knowledge base about how to effectively bring about systemic organizational change within higher education so that using evidence-based practices to support effective student learning becomes the new normal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this award was to support the inaugural meeting of the Accelerating Systemic Change Network (ASCN). The ultimate goal of ASCN is to advance the development of research-based knowledge concerning scaling and sustaining change in undergraduate STEM education. Other goals include providing training and professional development for faculty and other interested parties; fostering interactions among researchers and those in positions to pursue or enact change (change agents); supporting widespread adoption of beneficial practices in higher education; organizing and disseminating existing and future knowledge and resources in an accessible way; and accelerating the adoption of change efforts in STEM education.

The inaugural meeting of ASCN was held on July 6-8, 2016, at HHMI Headquarters in Chevy Chase, Maryland. There were 69 attendees representing a range of backgrounds and experiences related to pursuing change in undergraduate STEM education. This award supported travel for the attendees at this meeting, including the Steering Committee and others who were invited. At this inaugural meeting, four working groups were formed and two leaders were identified for each group. The original four working groups focus on the following topics: guiding theories of change; costs and benefits of change; change leadership; and measurement of change. These working groups continue to interact virtually to advance work in their areas. More information can be found at the ASCN website: https://ascnhighered.org.

Following the inaugural meeting, ASCN has held webinars, workshops, and institutes that have been well received and attended. Two additional working groups have formed. One focuses on equity and inclusion, and the other on aligning faculty work with systemic change. The inaugural meeting proved instrumental in providing a foundation and structure for the network, which has continued to grow towards achieving broader impact through these events and other meetings. As established at the inaugural meeting, a core purpose of this network is to bring together existing knowledge and resources that have not been connected in such a way in the past. At the meeting attendees were able to achieve many of the expected outcomes, including establishing a vision and structure for ASCN, producing ideas for new working groups, crafting initial agendas for these working groups, and creating lists of potential network members.

In terms of intellectual merit, the network represents an opportunity to expand the knowledge base regarding how to make systemic change happen in higher education. The inaugural meeting brought together many of the top researchers, future leaders, and change agents in relevant communities that are interested in working together collaboratively to improve STEM education. These attendees identified important areas for targeted work with the goal of accelerating change, and these areas became the focus of the working groups. Overall, the inaugural meeting provided ASCN with a strong foundation that has allowed the network to grow successfully and productively in its first two years.
